Islands, one measures .63 inch, and the other .53 inch in diameter; but the
average of the Polynesian specimens like that of the Philippine, Red Sea, and
Aegean, seems to be considerably lower than that of the Australian; and
their diameter seldom exceeds .25 of an inch, and is usually not more
than .10 or .12.

25 The disks formed on this plan, like the preceding, may be
 considered as typically circular, although they are seldom or never <s>so</s>
exactly so in reality. They may be considered, too, as typically flat with a slight
concavity in the central part, from which, however, the nucleus often
projects; but, as will hereafter appear, there is no constant relation
either between the thickness and the diameter of different specimens,
<s>n</s>or between the thickness of different parts of the same speciment; and
the distance of these parts from its centre. The only remarkable departure
from the ordinary form which I have met with, presents itself, in certain
Orbitolites from the Fejee Islands, of which several specimens in
the Royal College of Surgeons, and two in my own possession, exhibit
a curious plication towards their margins; the degree of this
departure varies so much, however, in different individuals, the plication
being almost obsolete in some (see Plate XI, Figs 12,13), that it cannot be admitted
